title: Report: Anfernee Simons played with wrist fracture during time with Celtics
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Anfernee Simons played with a wrist fracture during his time with the Boston Celtics, later aggravating it with the Bulls.
Simons averaged 14.2 points per game in 49 matches with the Celtics before being traded to the Bulls.
The Celtics traded Simons for Nikola Vucevic, who has averaged 9.9 points and 7.7 rebounds in seven games.

title: MBTA Commuter Rail experiences more delays due to snow cleanup and vehicle on track
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: MBTA Commuter Rail faces delays due to ongoing snow cleanup and a vehicle incident on the Worcester line.
Fairmount, Fall River/New Bedford, Fitchburg, and other lines affected; nearly three feet of snow complicates operations.
Keolis Commuter Services continues snow removal as MBTA services face criticism for handling of harsh winter conditions.

title: All Mass. residents to get free access to Google AI training classes, Healey says
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Massachusetts residents will have free access to Google's AI training through the Grow with Google program, announced Gov. Maura Healey.
Courses cover diverse tech subjects, including cybersecurity, digital marketing, data analytics, and AI professional certificates.
The initiative aims to boost AI skills and economic development in Massachusetts, supported by $100 million in funding.

title: Charlie McAvoy apologizes for Team USA’s reaction to Trump joke about US women’s team
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Charlie McAvoy apologized for Team USA men's hockey response to Trump's joke about the US women's team.
Team USA men's hockey celebrated Olympic gold with Trump; the women's team declined his invitation due to commitments.
Both US hockey teams won gold medals, strengthening their bond during the Milano-Cortina Winter Games.

title: Mayor Jake Wilson plans to tackle Somerville’s housing crisis. Will it work?
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Somerville Mayor Jake Wilson prioritizes increasing affordable and social housing to address the city's housing crisis.
The city added 2,046 housing units from 2020 to 2025, exceeding the region's growth rate, yet prices remain high.
Wilson supports rent stabilization and greater housing density near Green Line Extension stations to stabilize costs.

title: Watch this wild (and inspirational) video out of New Bedford following the blizzard
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: New Bedford streets remain snowy following Monday's blizzard, with many side streets yet to be fully plowed.
Local resident Scott Vicente drove his pickup truck through unplowed roads to check on properties and loved ones.
Vicente encourages drivers to avoid attempting snowy streets without proper vehicles, advising patience until plowing is complete.

title: 5 best new restaurant openings and dining updates in Boston (Feb. 26, 2026)
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Chef Douglass Williams opens La Tavernetta in East Boston, taking over the former Smoke Shop BBQ space.
Salt & Straw expands with a second New England location in Seaport, set to open late 2026.
Sorella Cucina Toscana, an Italian restaurant, opens in Burlington offering diverse pasta and crudo dishes.

title: Patriots still deciding what former defensive coordinator Terrell Williams’s role will be
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Terrell Williams remains with the Patriots, but his new role on Mike Vrabel’s staff is yet to be announced.
The team removed the interim tag from Zak Kuhr, appointing him as their new defensive coordinator after a successful season.
Williams, a former defensive coordinator, has past coaching experience with the Raiders, Dolphins, Titans, and Lions.

title: ‘Jeopardy!’ contestants struggled with a Boston category. Can you beat them?
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: 'Jeopardy!' contestants correctly answered three out of five questions in the Boston Space category on February 23.
The $600 Boston Space clue was incorrectly guessed as 'Harvard Yard' before Boston Common was correctly answered.
The $800 and $1000 Boston Space clues resulted in triple stumpers with no contestants attempting answers.

title: What we get wrong about sex, love, and monogamy
author: Meredith Goldstein
bullets: Kinsey Institute director Justin Garcia discusses intimacy, 'slow love,' and relationship perceptions on the Love Letters podcast.
Garcia's book explores the concepts of social and sexual monogamy and their impact on relationship satisfaction.
He describes 'slow love' as a cautious, prolonged courtship process popular among modern young people.
